div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
April 20, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements
Winner Winner, Chicken Dinner!  Look at all these beautiful birds that went home with families last Friday! Keep sending your reviews in; we love hearing them! 
"I warmed up the chicken in my cast iron and there were enough drippings to make amazing gravy! All I added was flour and water and it was so flavorful. Seriously this was the best roasted chicken I have ever had."
Roasted whole chickens will be back soon by popular demand - in the meantime, try our current BBQ chicken special, another fantastic meal from Chef Leah's repertoire! Roasted chicken thighs smothered in house BBQ sauce with scratch cornbread and garden salad with smokey seed dressing on the side. Serves 4-5! Order here
Friday Head of School Letter:

Hello Caregivers and Community! 

A reminder of the technology agreement we sent last Friday. I'm asking that families review this agreement and sign on to re-clarify with your student the expectations for students in our new learning environments.  Also, I'm highlighting this Expected Healthy Behaviors guide (these were updated over the weekend after keen eyes caught a typo!).

Coming up one month from today is our School Board election on May 21-22, 2020. We will primarily use digital voting (details to come). Our school board makes the decisions that guide the school and govern my job as school leader. Please consider getting involved and contributing your voice. The primary qualification for board members is that you care, you want to make this school a great place for all students, and you want to work with other board members to take responsibility for the school.

I highly encourage all caregivers and community members to apply. Currently, the board has 3 open seats: faculty, parent, and community member. More information about board work can be found here and you can click here for an application. For general questions please email office@greatriverschool.org. 

Thank you for building, carrying, and nurturing this community together,
Sam O'Brien
Head of School

This Week's Highlight: Mac 'n Cheese!
See what your students were so excited about every Tuesday? Our creamy family-sized mac n' cheese is scratchmade and served alongside expertly roasted vegetables and a garden salad with house smokey seed dressing. Serves 4-5!

Meal orders are due every Friday, with meal pickup the following Friday.
Order now! 
Dear UA families, 

Are you wondering about how Covid-19 is affecting the college process for the class of 2020 and 2021? Even if these changes are not happening to you or your child personally, the college admission world is changing at a rapid rate. A recent article from the Washington Post announced that colleges and universities are dropping their SAT/ACT requirements and many colleges (like Earlham) are waiving deposits and giving families more financial aid to deal with this economic stress. 

The best course of action if you or someone you know is planning to attend college in the fall is to contact the financial aid office and see what funds are available. As always, the GRS College Access Office is happy to answer any questions you may have! 

Teresa Hichens-Olson
Director of College Access 
          Ongoing Resources:
  • Make sure to bookmark our Learning From Home website - check there for distance learning handbooks, academic links, and all community resources shared thus far. 
  • Student Services Department Directory and Office Hours
  • Great River Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
  • The yearbook team will be working from home this spring to finalize this year's yearbook. Purchase one now on our website store.
  • New Heron-To-Go takeout menu (put it on your fridge!)

    Other Resources:
  • Xfinity WiFi Hotspot Access Opens Nationwide in Response to Coronavirus
  • Fungi Day: a virtual gathering celebrating the mycelial kingdom and how important this amazing world of organisms are to our survival.
  • Montreux Jazz Festival has made over 50 Festival concerts available to stream for free, including performances by Ray Charles, Wu-Tang Clan, Johnny Cash, Nina Simone, Marvin Gaye, Deep Purple, Carlos Santana, and more.
  • Virtual train rides from around the world 
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog. 
Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved.

You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.
**If you unsubscribe from this list, you will not receive any further communications on the school closure**

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
April 17, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements
We know there's lots to miss about physically going to school - seeing friends, teachers, and HOLLY! Going forward, you can expect a Holly Huddle every Friday, catching us up on all things Holly Bell. 
Holly Huddle #1
Hello, friends! I miss you!
Did you hear the tornado warning sirens yesterday? Do you know where to go in your house if there’s a real tornado? There’s one thing about me that you may not have guessed. I’m a tree hugger. I’ve been seen hugging trees. From the power of tornadoes and hurricanes (in Hawaii) to the majesty of waterfalls and rainbows, I am awestruck by Mother Nature. Speaking of Mother Nature, Wednesday is Earth Day. When I was very young, I used to ask my parents to help me send my allowance (25 cents/week) and birthday money to: Save The Whales. Can you think of a fun way to celebrate Earth Day?

On we go,
Holly
*Holly celebrates Fridays by wearing a Hawaiian print shirt. Which one today?
Friday Head of School Letter:

Hello families! 

Week two of distance learning is wrapped up! Please give us feedback here on this family feedback link. 

Also, I'm asking each family to sit down and review this technology agreement. Many families asked that we clarify expectations, and I'm asking that families review this agreement and sign on to re-clarify with your student the expectations for students in our new learning environments. 

And finally on this Friday - we have an additional way for you to reach out if your family is in need of support. This family support form is a place you can let us know if you are in need. We know of many social service resources, and we are hearing that many families are experiencing need for new and unexpected levels of support in housing, income, mental health, and food. 

Be well, keep in touch with us, reach out to help each other, 
Sam O'Brien
Head of School
 
Heron-To-Go: Housemade Pickles Now Available!

Sous Chef Mel is making pickles! For $5 a pint, these will become your family's new favorite side for everything! 🥒 
Pick(le) your favorite flavor - Sweet Bread & Butter, Classic Dill, Caraway Dill, Curry, or Garlic Dill. 

Meal orders are due every Friday, with meal pickup the following Friday.
Order now! 
New York Times Access for Adolescents
All 7-12th graders should have received an email with a link for free digital access to nytimes.com and the New York Times app. Once you log in, you’ll have access until July 6th. If you didn't receive a link, email office@greatriverschool.org! 
Greetings Great River Families,
 
While scrolling through the news, an article entitled “That Discomfort You’re Feeling is Grief,” caught my eye. It aptly named some of the feelings I have been experiencing as we continue to weather school closures and strict stay-at-home orders. It is likely that your child is also experiencing a level of grief, these feelings are difficult for children and adolescents to articulate, and can cause challenging behaviors.
 
As outlined in the article, we are experiencing loss and grief for everything that has changed in our lives, as well as for all our lost or canceled plans, including a great deal of special occasions. This is a level of collective grief that was unknown to us prior to the Covid-19 crisis. We are also experiencing anticipatory grief, which is the feeling we get when we are uncertain about what the future holds, and it breaks our sense of safety.
 
Our children may experience some or all of the different stages of grief (Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Sadness, and Acceptance), but not in a linear fashion. One example cited in the article described a normally cooperative child becoming very resistant to routine activities at home. When children cannot understand or articulate their feelings, they will often show you how they feel with behavior. One way to combat feelings of grief is to allow yourself, and your loved ones, to “feel your feelings”. Make sure you make space in your family structures to be sad together, to process the feelings of loss, and move forward together.
                    
All the best,
Michelle Flannery
School Psychologist

(Here's a longer article about elementary distance learning in times of disaster) 
 
What's Getting You Through? 
Last Friday, we asked the community to send us stories of what's getting you through: to share what's bolstering you, your family, or your community's resilience. Below are some of the emails we received. To share your story, email us at announcements@greatriverschool.org with the subject line "what's getting me through." 
  • Daily Walk of Love. I take an hour-long walk each day of the week. When work and school is complete for my household, I put on my sneakers and walk. A month ago I was calling these outings my daily Walk of Sanity. I've subverted that thinking, however, to call them what they truly are and have become over these last 4+ weeks of isolation: a daily Walk of Love. My Walk of Love gives me an opportunity to send out love to my community, myself, my family, my planet. Then I can return home refreshed with my love tank refilled.
  • Revised home workspace. Nature hikes and exploration with my kids. Family nightly gratefulness sharing. Running and biking at night.
          Ongoing Resources:
  • Make sure to bookmark our Learning From Home website - check there for distance learning handbooks, academic links, and all community resources shared thus far. 
  • Student Services Department Directory and Office Hours
  • Great River Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
  • The yearbook team will be working from home this spring to finalize this year's yearbook. Purchase one now on our website store.
  • New Heron-To-Go takeout menu (put it on your fridge!)

    Other Resources:
  • Reading Rainbow's' LeVar Burton To Livestream Readings Every Friday
  • Frank Lloyd Wright virtual house tours
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog. 
Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved.

You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.
**If you unsubscribe from this list, you will not receive any further communications on the school closure**

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
April 15, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements

Ah, the Senior Canoe Trip...by all accounts fun and rainy. Like, really rainy. Rainy in the...why won't this ever end...kind of way. Times like that are there to teach us that sometimes unwanted things happen, that are just completely out of our control. And sometimes those unwanted things are persistent and pervasive - like rain, like a pandemic. Our responses matter; validating and making space for our feelings, time to process, working towards acceptance, more rest, and always, having fun - the theme of this week's Wednesday Wellness newsletter
 
Wednesday Head of School Letter:

Hello Families, 
There's been a good deal of content sent to families these past two weeks. Here are some reference links so you can review items if you missed them! 
  • Guidance on Digital Tools for Families (Digital Boundaries)
  • GRS Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
Reminder that all our distance learning tools can be found at www.greatriverschool.org/athome
We will be sharing an updated family use agreement on Friday for you to review with your student(s). We miss you each!

Help each other, reach out for what you need, offer what you can. 

Sam O'Brien
Head of School
Heron-To-Go's Weekly Special: 
BBQ Chicken & Scratch Cornbread

Heron-To-Go has a new, simple takeout menu you can print off and keep on your fridge! Remember, orders are due every Friday at 4pm and can be picked up the following Friday from 11am-3pm. Thank you for supporting Great River School during this unprecedented school closure! Order food through our website here. 
Ongoing Resources:
  • Make sure to bookmark our Learning From Home website - check there for distance learning handbooks, academic links, and all community resources shared thus far. 
  • Student Services Department Directory and Office Hours
  • Great River Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
  • The yearbook team will be working from home this spring to finalize this year's yearbook. Purchase one now on our website store.
Other Resources:
  • Internet Options for Low-Income Families
  • Ramsey and Washington counties have created this website of Earth Day activities for kids and families (it's the 50th anniversary of Earth Day this year!)
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog. 
Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved.

You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.
**If you unsubscribe from this list, you will not receive any further communications on the school closure**

April 13, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements
Great River & Avalon's robotics team, NoMythic, qualified for the FIRST Robotics World Championships this year, right before the competition was canceled due to COVID-19. Rather than put their energy into prepping for the competition, team members are using their technical skills to better their community and join the fight to flatten the curve. Members are sewing face masks, donating boxes of safety glasses to local care facilities, and 3D-printing face shields for front-line workers. Click here to read their press release!
Monday Head of School Letter:

Families - Thank you for opening this new school with us in April 2020! After one week of distance learning, I have received many helpful observations and contributions from our community. Please keep us informed about your experience! (emails to office@greatriverschool.org and/or directly to me are helpful!) 

We will be sharing an updated learning agreement for distance learning this week by Friday 4/17. Please make time to sit down as caregiver and student to read over the agreement and make sure you understand it together. 

Thank you each and all!

Sam O'Brien
Head of School
sobrien@greatriverschool.org
 
Donated Meals Available!
Has your family been experiencing hardship from Covid-19 and would love some help putting a meal on the table? The GRS community is here to help! Many meals have been donated by GRS families and are waiting to be claimed. Fill out this form if you are in need of a delicious family meal that feeds 4-5. 

You can see all the kitchen's offerings at www.greatriverschool.org/herontogo
 
From Holly:
While you're learning from home, you can still help our school by claiming Box Tops! Box Tops went digital last year, so all you need is the digital app and your receipt. Right now, the app is offering bonus Box Tops on specific products - click here to see more info. 

Hi all! 

Does anyone else feel like their life exists in the virtual world of Zoom right now? Given that our social connections and learning exist online for the time being, it can be frustrating that we're spending so much time looking and talking to a screen, especially since we've heard so much about how screen time affects children's health and development. All of the norms and limits that you've set for your children may need to be reworked, but what does healthy screen time look like right now? Check out this Edutopia article that summarizes some recommendations made by the American Academy of Pediatrics for healthy screen use during Covid-19. Remember to give yourselves and your families patience and grace - we're all learning how to navigate this new online world together!

Wishing you all the best, 
Liv Sandin
Elementary Social Worker
lsandin@greatriverschool.org
We've recently gotten a handful of requests for yearbooks. A reminder you can always order a 19/20 yearbook on our website store.

Ongoing Resources:
  • Make sure to bookmark our Learning From Home website - check there for distance learning handbooks, academic links, and all community resources shared thus far. 
  • Student Services Department Directory and Office Hours
  • Great River Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
Other Resources:
  • Click here to see an updated spreadsheet of all community resources shared on this newsletter so far (also linked on the Learning From Home site). 
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog. 
Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved.

You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.
**If you unsubscribe from this list, you will not receive any further communications on the school closure**

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
April 10, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements

Our first Heron-To-Go family meal packages were picked up today! Chef Leah took these incredible shots of the beautiful whole roasted chickens and garden salads going home with families today. Remember, Heron-To-Go orders are due every Friday at 4pm, with pickup the following Friday. To see all available items or to get in on this chicken goodness, click here: www.greatriverschool.org/herontogo. Thank you for supporting our school's nutrition team during this unprecedented school closure!
Friday Head of School Letter:

Dear families,

Our first week of distance learning is coming to a close, and we need to hear from you!!! Please take 3-5 minutes and tell us what worked, what could be better, and how we can all work together best.

An update on our school calendar for this year: We are making contingency plans for events, gatherings, and in-person programming at Great River. All in-person meetings are be postponed until we get direction otherwise from state officials. We will communicate about rescheduling in-person events (like Info Nights) by April 20th.

Also, we want all families in Saint Paul to be aware of a special grant with funds for qualifying families. See here for more information. 

Be well all,
Sam O'Brien
Head of School
 
Hey Great River Students, Families, and Staff! 

The Student Services Department wants to know....
What's getting you through?

Send us your stories, video or audio clips, sharing one thing that's bolstering you, your family, or your community's resilience. 

I'll give an example:
One thing that is getting me through is napping! Usually, I feel good without naps if my sleep routine stays constant. But I've noticed during times where my emotions are running higher than usual, a midday nap really helps me reset - some days it is so helpful to have a moment to completely relax. 

Flood us with your examples! We'll roll them out a few at a time, in every Friday newsletter.
Send them to announcements@greatriverschool.org with the subject line, 'What's getting me through...'

We care about you so much!
Sincerely, 
Jenny & The Student Services Department 
Ongoing Resources:
  • Make sure to bookmark our Learning From Home website - check there for distance learning handbooks, academic links, and all community resources shared thus far. 
  • Student Services Department Directory and Office Hours
  • Great River Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
  • We've recently gotten a handful of requests for yearbooks. A reminder you can always order a 19/20 yearbook on our website store.
Other Resources:
  • How to reduce bandwidth use while video conferencing 
  • Free New York Times subscriptions for high schoolers
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog. 
Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved.

You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.
**If you unsubscribe from this list, you will not receive any further communications on the school closure**

April 8, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements

Goats are just naughty dogs - always on the move, always after snacks, always in your pockets. Welcome again, always, to Wednesday Wellness, co-written by members of the Student Services Department. At Great River, we're the group that seeks holistic ways to make school possible in the best way for our students. Our theme this week is "Movement". Like goats, like naughty dogs, most people have drives that need to be met to keep us balanced, to allow us to do a variety of work. Movement can "put us in our bodies", giving us a sense of peace, a sense of being grounded, a sense of calm.
Click here to read our second issue! 
Wednesday Head of School Letter:

As we move through the mechanics of becoming digitally connected, I want to offer guidance on the next layer of caring for our connection. This is especially for families of younger students - and useful reflection for everyone. Here are my thoughts and a few one-page resources and references for you as a family. 

Sam O'Brien
Head of School
Give Food to the Community, Get Family Meals From the Kitchen!
The Heron's Nest Cafe is continuing to serve all your favorites! You can see offerings and preorder meals for your family here. You can also anonymously donate a meal to a GRS family or request a free meal if you are a family in need!

Meal orders are due every Friday, with meal pickup the following Friday. 
 
We've recently gotten a handful of requests for yearbooks. A reminder you can always order a 19/20 yearbook on our website store.

Ongoing Resources:
  • Make sure to bookmark our Learning From Home website - check there for distance learning handbooks, academic links, and all community resources shared thus far. 
  • Student Services Department Directory and Office Hours
  • Great River Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
Other Resources:
  • Code It – Helps children learn basic programming concepts through online courses, live webinars and other kid-friendly material.
  • GoNoodle - free exercise and mindfulness videos for elementary students
  • St. Paul Chamber Orchestra - free digital concert on April 18th 
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog. 
Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved.

You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.
**If you unsubscribe from this list, you will not receive any further communications on the school closure**

*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
April 6, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements
Monday Head of School Letter:

Great River Families - 

We want to know how learning at home was for you today - please fill out this survey and let us know! This should take 3-5 minutes.  Comments are optional - though specific comments help us address what's going on!
 
We will use this information to address general patterns, see where we can improve, and make sure we highlight what's going well for you. 

Thanks for taking a minute to help out the community with your experience! 

Sam O'Brien
Head of School

Happy first day of distance learning! As we all adjust to our new normal, check out this Video Conferencing Do's & Don'ts tutorial, made by Elementary guides. 

Welcome back, Great River students and families! I know I'm really looking forward to connecting with many of you and hearing how you're doing. As we enter into this new distance learning endeavor, I wanted to offer a visually pleasing and simple breathing technique that I've found helpful: square breathing. Always, but especially in times of transition, breathing can be a helpful technique to root us in our bodies, soothe, and energize ourselves. For those of you for whom this technique doesn't feel helpful, you can try just letting your eyes follow the ball as it moves around the square, or just noticing what parts of your body are being supported by a chair, couch, or the ground. 

Take care all!
Ori Wasserburg
owasserburg@greatriverschool.org
6B, 7/8 Social Worker
In the middle of this upheaval, we've gotten a handful of requests for yearbooks. A reminder you can always order a 19/20 yearbook on our website store. 

Ongoing Resources:
  • Make sure to bookmark our Learning From Home website - check there for distance learning handbooks, academic links, and all community resources shared thus far. 
  • Student Services Department Directory and Office Hours
  • Great River Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
Other Resources:
  • From Holly: Wildlife Projects for Kids
  • Free audio stories to support children with shelter-in-place
  • Minneapolis Institute of Arts has launched Mia From Home; you can explore the bulk of their collection from your couch!
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog.

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge
Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
April 1, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements
Monday's the big day! Our community-building distance learning starts!
 
Quick Link Reminders:
Learning From Home website (new! bookmark this!)
Where and when you connect on Monday
Our Learning From Home handbook (also linked on the front page of our website)
Friday Head of School Letter:

Families! 

There are ways we can predict what will be good on Monday: faces, voices, lovely relationships restarted in our new routines. And there are ways we cannot predict what will be needed - for we are going together into the unknown. We have a plan, and of course the world and weather and internet connection will have their way with our plans. So - thank you for your patience and your participation in building our community of learning anew on Monday, April 6th. We look forward to seeing you!

We will have materials for pickup on Monday 9-11am or 1-3pm. If you need a computer from school, or your elementary printed materials, or things from school like your shoes or coats or folders, please come in those times to get them. (If you can print your own elementary materials, wonderful - find them linked at our Learning From Home website: www.greatriverschool.org/athome. We have updates for each level that we’ll keep current.)

Remember to email office@greatriverschool.org with feedback or needs as we move forward. Elementary families, if you can't get your materials or packets Monday or have questions, email us!

One last thought as we approach April 6th - we are entering a second phase of this pandemic disruption for our children. We are starting routines that are new, but with familiar people. Those people won’t be in familiar places though, they will be images on a screen. So, expect a bit of heavy emotion. Expect that the tide will be coming in and going out in unpredictable ways. Expect some challenge and frustration, and some sorrow that we are not together in person, but reminding each other of why school is a place we love together. 

I'lll share on Monday 4/6 some guidelines for online grace and courtesy and etiquette, and some sanity seeking for families of younger students who are just wading into a life more online than it was a month ago. In the meantime, I’ve shared a Wendell Berry poem below (shared with me by our Bike Shop guide Johnny Wakefield). The poem speaks to knowing ourselves and our place as a way to be prepared for these times. 

May we all understand each other better, 

Sam O’Brien
 

A Poem on Hope

It is hard to have hope. It is harder as you grow old,
for hope must not depend on feeling good
and there’s the dream of loneliness at absolute midnight.
You also have withdrawn belief in the present reality
of the future, which surely will surprise us,
and hope is harder when it cannot come by prediction
anymore than by wishing. But stop dithering.
The young ask the old to hope. What will you tell them?
Tell them at least what you say to yourself.

Because we have not made our lives to fit
our places, the forests are ruined, the fields, eroded,
the streams polluted, the mountains, overturned. Hope
then to belong to your place by your own knowledge
of what it is that no other place is, and by
your caring for it, as you care for no other place, this
knowledge cannot be taken from you by power or by wealth.
It will stop your ears to the powerful when they ask
for your faith, and to the wealthy when they ask for your land
and your work.  Be still and listen to the voices that belong
to the stream banks and the trees and the open fields.

Find your hope, then, on the ground under your feet.
Your hope of Heaven, let it rest on the ground underfoot.
The world is no better than its places. Its places at last
are no better than their people while their people
continue in them. When the people make
dark the light within them, the world darkens.

–Wendell Berry
Give Food to the Community, Get Family Meals From the Kitchen!
The Heron's Nest Cafe is continuing to serve all your favorites! (Even while school isn't physically in session - our kitchen is making fresh and safe to take home food.) Please support our Nutrition program and support GRS families needing help: you can see offerings and preorder meals for your family here. You can also anonymously donate a meal to a GRS family or request a meal if you are a family in need! 
 
Bookmark this link to see where you can order meals through the spring!
Ongoing Resources:
  • Great River Community Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
  • Student Services Directory & Office Hours
  • Family Directory
Other Resources:
  • Nikon is offering free photography classes for all of April 
  • The Minneapolis American Indian Center is offering free, online language classes in both Dakota & Objiwe.
  • Tips for talking to children about infectious disease outbreaks
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog. 
Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved.

1326 Energy Park Drive
Saint Paul, MN, 55108
office@greatriverschool.org

Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.

***If you unsubscribe from this list, you will not receive any further public health updates from the school***

(If you can print your own elementary materials, wonderful - find them linked at our Learning From Home website: www.greatriverschool.org/athome. We have updates for each level that we’ll keep current.) Remember to email office@greatriverschool.org with feedback or needs as we move forward. Elementary families, if you can't get your materials or packets Monday or have questions, email us! One last thought as we approach April 6th - we are entering a second phase of this pandemic disruption for our children. We are starting routines that are new, but with familiar people. Those people won’t be in familiar places though, they will be images on a screen. So, expect a bit of heavy emotion. Expect that the tide will be coming in and going out in unpredictable ways. Expect some challenge and frustration, and some sorrow that we are not together in person, but reminding each other of why school is a place we love together.  I'lll share on Monday 4/6 some guidelines for online grace and courtesy and etiquette, and some sanity seeking for families of younger students who are just wading into a life more online than it was a month ago. In the meantime, I’ve shared a Wendell Berry poem below (shared with me by our Bike Shop guide Johnny Wakefield). The poem speaks to knowing ourselves and our place as a way to be prepared for these times.  May we all understand each other better,  Sam O’Brien   A Poem on Hope It is hard to have hope. It is harder as you grow old, for hope must not depend on feeling good and there’s the dream of loneliness at absolute midnight. You also have withdrawn belief in the present reality of the future, which surely will surprise us, and hope is harder when it cannot come by prediction anymore than by wishing. But stop dithering. The young ask the old to hope. What will you tell them? Tell them at least what you say to yourself. Because we have not made our lives to fit our places, the forests are ruined, the fields, eroded, the streams polluted, the mountains, overturned. Hope then to belong to your place by your own knowledge of what it is that no other place is, and by your caring for it, as you care for no other place, this knowledge cannot be taken from you by power or by wealth. It will stop your ears to the powerful when they ask for your faith, and to the wealthy when they ask for your land and your work.  Be still and listen to the voices that belong to the stream banks and the trees and the open fields. Find your hope, then, on the ground under your feet. Your hope of Heaven, let it rest on the ground underfoot. The world is no better than its places. Its places at last are no better than their people while their people continue in them. When the people make dark the light within them, the world darkens. –Wendell Berry Give Food to the Community, Get Family Meals From the Kitchen! The Heron's Nest Cafe is continuing to serve all your favorites! (Even while school isn't physically in session - our kitchen is making fresh and safe to take home food.) Please support our Nutrition program and support GRS families needing help: you can see offerings and preorder meals for your family here. You can also anonymously donate a meal to a GRS family or request a meal if you are a family in need!    Bookmark this link to see where you can order meals through the spring! Ongoing Resources: Great River Community Mutual Aid Spreadsheet Student Services Directory & Office Hours Family Directory Other Resources: Nikon is offering free photography classes for all of April  The Minneapolis American Indian Center is offering free, online language classes in both Dakota & Objiwe. Tips for talking to children about infectious disease outbreaks For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org. Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog.  Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved. 1326 Energy Park Drive Saint Paul, MN, 55108 office@greatriverschool.org Want to change how you receive these emails? You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list. ***If you unsubscribe from this list, you will not receive any further public health updates from the school***

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
April 1, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements
Give Food to the Community, Get Family Meals From the Kitchen!
The Heron's Nest Cafe is continuing to serve all your favorites! (Even while school isn't physically in session - our kitchen is making fresh and safe to take home food.) Please support our Nutrition program and support GRS families needing help: you can see offerings and preorder meals for your family here. You can also anonymously donate a meal to a GRS family or request a meal if you are a family in need! 

Bookmark this link to see where you can order meals through the spring!
Wednesday Head of School Letter:

Families of Great River School! We are developing a “Learning At Home” landing page on our website that will go live on or just before 4/6/2020. We will update that page with the latest information on learning by level. 
In anticipation of 4/6/2020, here’s an easy-to-reference table on when and how to be ready to engage with your guides and adults at GRS!

For elementary students accessing email for the first time, we have guidance coming on Friday! Your family will receive a clarifying email (Friday) on how to log into email, where to go for help, and how to log into a school Chromebook if you have one from us at your home! 

If you find that your student cannot complete the work required with the technology you have available, please let us know at office@greatriverschool.org.  We will work with every family to ensure students can access the tools necessary to learn from home. Pickup of materials (either technology or items from school) can happen Monday 4/6 between 9-11am or 1-3pm. Contact office@greatriverschool.org with questions. 

Thanks everyone - for your generosity and community spirit as we grow into this together!
Sam O'Brien
Head of School
Hello Students!
Guides at Great River School are taking spring break to rest up and be ready for next week. We are excited to see you and hear from you all again starting Monday. Thanks for your patience, and your love for your caregivers - we look forward to starting our learning from home plans next week!
Ongoing Resources:
  • Great River Community Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
  • Student Services Directory & Office Hours
  • Family Directory
Other Resources:
  • Minnesota DNR's EagleCam live stream is fun to watch - local baby eagles!
  • New England Aquarium has lots of virtual visit videos available 
  • Huge spreadsheet of virtual field trips and activities!
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog. 
Copyright © 2020 Great River School, All rights reserved.

1326 Energy Park Drive
Saint Paul, MN, 55108
office@greatriverschool.org

Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
March 30, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements

Spring Break 2020! A spring break unlike any we anticipated! When we find ourselves in brand new waters, a familiar sea shanty can be the balm we need. Above, adolescent students sing "Morning Shanty" (unprompted by any guides) while waiting for a late bus in 2018. Cultivating community, connection, and shared experience can see us through choppy waters.  We have our Learning From Home Handbook ready - see link below!
Monday Head of School Letter:
We've formatted our distance learning plan and linked it on the cover page of our website. This is the start of what we will develop together - please stay in touch about what works, what is challenging, and how we can make this work for all our students. 

Be well, stay safe, and offer up a generous spirit, 
Sam O'Brien
Head of School
Family Meals For Sale from Great River School Kitchen
The Heron's Nest will continue serving all your favorites during school closure! Please support our Nutrition program as we face an unprecedented school closure. You can see offerings and preorder meals at our new website and online store here. 
Ongoing Resources:
  • Great River Community Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
    What are some ways you could use some help right now? We've put together this GRS Mutual Aid spreadsheet for our community to engage with, with spreadsheet tabs to input your needs and what you have to offer, as well as links to neighborhood pods that have already begun to form.
  • Student Services
    A reminder that one foundation of support for your family can be Great River’s Student Services Team. Click here for an introductory letter sent out last week, explaining ongoing support, and here for a directory and (remote) office hours of social workers, academic interventionists, and other student support staff available during this school closure. 
  • Family Directory
    Click here to see a spreadsheet of all family's contact information, for setting up Zoom playdates or any other social distancing creative socialization.
Other Resources:
  • The Calm app is offering many free mindfulness, meditation, and breathing exercises. 
  • Outschool: Live online classes on a variety of subjects for ages 3-18
  • Giant list of resources for parents and caregivers 
  • A reminder that there are four (active) Great River parent facebook groups. These groups are not run or monitored by the school, but are good places for families to connect with each other: 
    Elementary Parent FB Group
    Lower Adolescent Parent FB Group
    Upper Adolescent FB Group
    General Great River School Community Parent FB Group
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog.

Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
March 27, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements

The Upper Adolescent Community Meeting Team (Piper & Emily) made this great video of ways to stave off boredom during quarantine. All of us at Great River - guides, admin, and livestock - wish you a restful, although unconventional, spring break. You can expect this newsletter in your inbox as normal - Monday, Wednesday, and Friday - next week, although guides will not have regular office hours. Urgent concerns can always be sent to office@greatriverschool.org. Be well! 
Friday Head of School Letter:
Great River School adults have worked tirelessly since March 18th creating a learning plan that sustains our community. We seek to engage the will and imagination of our students and create a Montessori learning environment at your home. That learning environment at your home will be a reflection of how well we combine several ingredients - care from us, care from you, and engagement of imagination and will of your student. We will publish a full handbook on 3/30/20 and send it to you; click here for a summary of that handbook and our work. 

Be well - offer someone help - ask for what you need,
Sam O'Brien
Head of School
Heron-To-Go!
The Heron's Nest will continue serving all your favorites during school closure! Please support our Nutrition program as we face an unprecedented school closure. You can see offerings and preorder meals at our new website and online store here. 
Technology Needs for Distance Learning
As we roll out the plans for distance learning and your family begins to put them into action after the break, you may find that your tech needs differ from when you first submitted the tech survey. 

If you find that your student cannot complete the work required with the technology you have available, please let us know at office@greatriverschool.org.  We will work with every family to ensure students can access the tools necessary to learn from home.

As we prepare for a statewide shelter in place order that coincides with the start of our spring break, I wanted to share some activities and points of connection that are helping my family beat the spring-cabin-Covid-fever and also keep in touch with friends and families:

  • This link to the Big Life Journal (which has resources we use often at school for executive functioning) has extensive activity lists we have printed and magnet-ed to our fridge at home. Some family favorites include "The Floor is Lava", dance parties, Cosmic Kids Yoga, and putting daily artwork in the windows for our neighbors. 
     
  • The other brand new app we discovered last night is Caribu. We used this for the first time after a hilarious, but challenging video phone call with grandparents trying to read and hold up a Berenstain Bears book. Caribu lets you both view a book on screen and read together over the app. There are also art and game functions that are shareable via videoconferencing. This morning, our kids have been virtually coloring together with their regular playmates and playing tic-tac-toe with Grandpa. 

Although we can't wait to see folks in person again, these are also tools we'll likely keep in our family kit longterm to spend time with cousins that live across the country. 

Matt McElrath
Dean of Students
Ongoing Resources:
  • Great River Community Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
    What are some ways you could use some help right now? We've put together this GRS Mutual Aid spreadsheet for our community to engage with, with spreadsheet tabs to input your needs and what you have to offer, as well as links to neighborhood pods that have already begun to form.
  • Student Services
    A reminder that one foundation of support for your family can be Great River’s Student Services Team. Click here for an introductory letter sent out last week, explaining ongoing support, and here for a directory and (remote) office hours of social workers, academic interventionists, and other student support staff available during this school closure. 
  • Family Directory
    Click here to see a spreadsheet of all family's contact information, for setting up Zoom playdates or any other social distancing creative socialization.
Other Resources:
  • California State Parks PORTS Program: The Home Learning Program offers virtual field trips four times a week!  
  • Khan Academy: Live online classes on a variety of subjects for ages 4-18
  • Outschool: Live online classes on a variety of subjects for ages 3-18
  • Giant list of resources for parents and caregivers 
  • A reminder that there are four (active) Great River parent facebook groups. These groups are not run or monitored by the school, but are good places for families to connect with each other: 
    Elementary Parent FB Group
    Lower Adolescent Parent FB Group
    Upper Adolescent FB Group (new!)
    General Great River School Community Parent FB Group
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog.

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge
Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
March 25, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements

...ahhh, the 2019 bike trip...look at those smiles! Look at that green, green grass! Look at that social BIKE distancing! Welcome, welcome to the first-ever Wellness Wednesday newsletter from the Student Services Department. You can look forward to these special edition newsletters once a week, every Wednesday. We've created this weekly correspondence as a way for all of us to be in community with all of you.
Because it's important. Because you are important to us. Because you are important to this community.
 

Our theme this week is "Connection" - click here to read our first issue!

Wednesday Head of School Letter:

Families,

We all heard today that Governor Walz will be starting a shelter-in-place order for Minnesota. We at Great River School are preparing to serve you and our students with care and forethought. 

On Friday, I'll be in touch regarding specifics for our distance learning plan. We will include a second family survey on Friday 3/27 to make sure we know your needs. In the meantime, please fill out the survey from our kitchen team - we want to keep our nutrition program open and in order to do so, we need to feed our community. Please consider buying food from us!

We miss you and our students. We look forward to starting our distance learning plan on Monday April 6th. That first day will make sure you are connected and ready to re-engage in Montessori learning at home. We are all ready for our students' learning to be guided by our intrepid and loving adults.
 

Be well, all that may, 
Sam O'Brien
Head of School

Kitchen Exploring Meals-at-Home Options
GRS families! Do you miss Chicken Thursdays? Do you need a quick and easy way to get breakfast and lunch and dinner on the table?

We're ready to cook amazing food for you to take out! We will start offering food for purchase and pick-up as soon as April 9th. We want to know how many families are going to get our delicious food. Fill out this survey and let us know what weekly meal options your family would be interested in. We'd offer all the kitchen's big hits (Rita's fried rice, mac n' cheese, roasted chicken, and more). We also are considering offering weekly breakfast and lunch packs so your students can take independence in preparing their meal. 

If your family receives free or reduced lunch and is in need of food immediately, please let us know by filling out this survey (sent out last week). All FRL-qualifying families will continue to receive their breakfast and lunch packs. 
Great River Community Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
What are some ways you could use some help right now? We've put together this GRS Mutual Aid spreadsheet for our community to engage with, with spreadsheet tabs to input your needs and what you have to offer, as well as links to neighborhood pods that have already begun to form.

Student Services
A reminder that one foundation of support for your family can be Great River’s
Student Services Team. Click here for an introductory letter sent out last week, explaining ongoing support, and here for a directory and (remote) office hours of social workers, academic interventionists, and other student support staff available during this school closure. 

Family Directory
Click here to see a spreadsheet of all family's contact information, for setting up Zoom playdates or any other social distancing creative socialization. 

Other Resources:
  • National Association of School Psychologist's guidelines to combatting Covid-19 stigma

  • Giant list of resources for parents and caregivers 

  • A reminder that there are three (active) Great River parent facebook groups. These groups are not run or monitored by the school, but are good places for families to connect with each other: 
    Elementary Parent FB Group
    Lower Adolescent Parent FB Group
    General Great River School Community Parent FB Group
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org.
Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog.

why did I get this?    unsubscribe from this list    update subscription preferences
*|LIST:ADDRESSLINE|*

We are all ready for our students' learning to be guided by our intrepid and loving adults.   Be well, all that may,  Sam O'Brien Head of School Kitchen Exploring Meals-at-Home Options GRS families! Do you miss Chicken Thursdays? Do you need a quick and easy way to get breakfast and lunch and dinner on the table? We're ready to cook amazing food for you to take out! We will start offering food for purchase and pick-up as soon as April 9th. We want to know how many families are going to get our delicious food. Fill out this survey and let us know what weekly meal options your family would be interested in. We'd offer all the kitchen's big hits (Rita's fried rice, mac n' cheese, roasted chicken, and more). We also are considering offering weekly breakfast and lunch packs so your students can take independence in preparing their meal.  If your family receives free or reduced lunch and is in need of food immediately, please let us know by filling out this survey (sent out last week). All FRL-qualifying families will continue to receive their breakfast and lunch packs.  Great River Community Mutual Aid Spreadsheet What are some ways you could use some help right now? We've put together this GRS Mutual Aid spreadsheet for our community to engage with, with spreadsheet tabs to input your needs and what you have to offer, as well as links to neighborhood pods that have already begun to form. Student Services A reminder that one foundation of support for your family can be Great River’s Student Services Team. Click here for an introductory letter sent out last week, explaining ongoing support, and here for a directory and (remote) office hours of social workers, academic interventionists, and other student support staff available during this school closure.  Family Directory Click here to see a spreadsheet of all family's contact information, for setting up Zoom playdates or any other social distancing creative socialization.  Other Resources: National Association of School Psychologist's guidelines to combatting Covid-19 stigma Giant list of resources for parents and caregivers  A reminder that there are three (active) Great River parent facebook groups. These groups are not run or monitored by the school, but are good places for families to connect with each other:  Elementary Parent FB Group Lower Adolescent Parent FB Group General Great River School Community Parent FB Group For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org. Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check the school's Announcements Blog.  This email was sent to *|EMAIL|* why did I get this?    unsubscribe from this list    update subscription preferences *|LIST:ADDRESSLINE|*

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
March 23, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements
One of the most important antidotes to big feelings we may be experiencing is feeling connected - above is a video of how our elementary staff stayed connected last Friday after a week of distance education planning. Today's edition of the GRS Public Health Newsletter contains some big news about IB testing and some helpful community resources. Remember, to see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check our Announcements Blog. 
Monday Head of School Letter:

All the guides and adults working for the school are deeply engaged in preparations for how we learn from home starting next month. We anticipate that learning from home will be guided by the Montessori expertise our staff bring to their work, and we will be working out new solutions to making sure families and students can connect with each other by phone, by video, and through meaningful connections and conversations that are public-health compliant. 

Basically, we envision phone calls and possible video calls between your student and the adults who care for their learning. We also envision supplying structured time, structured presentations and lessons, as well as meaningful one-to-one connections and conversations between adults and students. Great River School thrives because of the caring relationships between guides and students, and our distance learning plan will reflect that same care. We look forward to sharing details with you when our plan is done at the end of this week. 

And why wait on sending you the plan until the end of the week? We are working to make sure we are prepared to provide the resources needed to make the work successful. This includes how to assure the technology, the possible need to pickup or dropoff materials, and the need to create new systems for connection are ironed out before we share them. Once we send you the plan, we will attach a follow-up survey so you can let us know specific needs that your student and family may have for academics, technology, nutrition, or any other way we will be working together through the spring. 

Also, we miss you! We want to see your faces and hear your voices! You’ll hear from us again in our Wednesday Public Health Community Newsletter!

Sam O'Brien
Head of School

IB Exams Canceled Spring 2020
The International Baccalaureate Organization has announced that the May 2020 examinations scheduled between 4/30-5/22 for Diploma Programme and Career-related Programme candidates will no longer be held. Students still will receive an official IB score - click here to read more.
 
Great River Community Mutual Aid Spreadsheet
What are some ways you could use some help right now? We've put together this GRS Mutual Aid spreadsheet for our community to engage with, with spreadsheet tabs to input your needs and what you have to offer, as well as links to neighborhood pods that have already begun to form.

Student Services
A reminder that one foundation of support for your family can be Great River’s
Student Services Team. Click here for an introductory letter sent out last week, explaining ongoing support, and here for a directory and (remote) office hours of social workers, academic interventionists, and other student support staff available during this school closure. 

Family Directory
Click here to see a spreadsheet of all family's contact information, for setting up Zoom playdates or any other social distancing creative socialization. 

Other Resources:
  • From Social Work Team:
    Greater Good Science Center's Guide to Pandemic Wellbeing
  • From Holly:
    How to Grow an Herb Garden Indoors 
  • From Melanie:
    Click here for some resources on improving your well-being and mental health during the current coronavirus pandemic.
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org

div.div:
*|MC:SUBJECT|* *|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
March 20, 2020
 Donate / Faculty Directory / Announcements
Welcome to the second edition of the GRS Public Health Community Newsletter! We will continue sending this family newsletter three times a week - Monday, Wednesday, and Friday - to keep folks apprised of the fast-moving situation. To see all public health newsletters in one place, you can always check our Announcements Blog. 
Friday Head of School Letter
We have been using our time this week to plan for distance learning that reflects our Montessori program and priorities. We want students to experience as much cohesion, connection, and engagement with their work... (read more)

Student Services at Great River
At this time of upheaval, one foundation of support for your family can be Great River School Student Services Team. Click here for an introductory letter sent out on Wednesday, explaining ongoing support, and here for a directory and (remote) office hours of social workers, academic interventionists, and other student support staff. 

Student Meals During School Closure
School Great River School will continue to provide breakfast and lunches to students whose families request it during this break from school - click here for more information if your family wants to continue receiving school meals!

Health Information
Our school nurse consultants have put together some information for GRS families regarding COVID-19 signs and symptoms. No cases associated with Great River School have yet been reported. Families are always welcome to email Natalie at health@greatriverschool.org for any school-related health questions.
Tapping as Stress Relief
Saleha and Ricardo demonstrate a calming technique called tapping in this video.  If you want to explore more about tapping, here are some additional resources. (link and link). 

CAS Update for Juniors & Seniors
Melanie sent this message to junior & senior families this week to share how we are supporting 11/12th grade students in Great River School's Creativity, Activity, and Service (CAS) graduation requirement as we transition to potential distance learning. 

IB Diploma Candidates - Extended Essay Supports
Adam & Lindsey sent this message to outline the ways the school will support students' Extended Essay planning and progress this spring. 

Message from IB Coordinator
Senior IB candidates and families: have no fear! Our talented IB guides are monitoring and working with the IB throughout our school closure. No action is needed from you at this time. Stay tuned to your MangeBac calendar and ensure you continue to meet GRS deadlines. Email Lindsey with any questions at lweaver@greatriverschool.org. 
On Cooperation + Mutual Aid
Consider how you can be a resource to your neighbors and community. What are the skill sets that you have and are willing to offer? What are some ways you could use some help right now? We've put together this GRS Mutual Aid spreadsheet for our community to engage with, with spreadsheet tabs to input your needs and what you have to offer, as well as links to neighborhood pods that have already begun to form

Wanting to explore the concept of mutual aid more as a family at home? Check out Shingobee guide, Alaina's lesson on mutual aid here.

Family Directory
This link was updated yesterday!
For ongoing questions, check our Family FAQ or email office@greatriverschool.org
Copyright © 2020 Great River School

You are receiving this email as a community member of Great River School. 
You can update your preferences or unsubscribe from this list.

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge
Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge

div.class: image-block-outer-wrapper layout-caption-below design-layout-inline combination-animation-none individual-animation-none individual-text-animation-none

p.em: (to see this memo in google doc format -

div.p: Hello families!

Sam O’Brien, your head of school, reporting here and introducing you to a tri-weekly newsletter. This is the first of regular Monday-Wednesday-Friday communications to families from Great River. This is a direct email to you to keep you informed and make sure we’re all on the same page about what’s happening.

Below is a format that lays out the highlights of the newsletter today. Contents below include a letter from me as Head of School, a letter from our Student Wellness team, and a start of resources for you as a family and caregiver for your kids. Thanks all for your patience and love for each other as we live through these troubled times.
~Sam O’Brien

p.strong: 1. What’s happened in the last few days?

div.p: Faculty have been meeting in small groups on campus and via video conferencing to start building long-distance curriculum plans. Our cleaning company is continuing to clean our building and disinfect public spaces and surfaces.

p.strong: 2. What’s coming up? What’s the latest?

div.p: Click here for a clarification letter from Sam on what the school closure means for curriculum and when you can expect to hear more specifics on distance learning going forward.

p.strong: 3. How are you feeling? How’s your family doing?

div.p: A letter of introduction from our student services team on introducing you to the work that the Student Services Department does - social work, wellness, support and care.

p.strong: 4. Where to go with questions: if you have any questions for the school, please email

div.p: Also, here’s the Frequently Asked Questions we have published!

a.span: Family Directory - current as of 10/2019 (update coming soon!
Giant list of resources for parents and caregivers

li.p: The Flatten the Curve facebook group has compiled resources of virtual concerts, resources, and other interactive tools - good for both distance learning and personal boredom!
Check out this compiled list of 30 virtual field trips for all ages

article.class: entry h-entry hentry category-upper-adolescent category-lower-adolescent category-elementary category-bridge author-charlie-zieke post-type-text article-index-16

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge

h1.a: GRS Closed 3/17; REQUIRED FAMILY SURVEY INSIDE

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge

div.p: Due to developing public health specifics, and our cooperation with the Minnesota Department of Health, Great River School will be closed tomorrow, March 17th, including all childcare and school activities.
Childcare will be available March 18-27 for healthcare workers, civil emergency workers, and families who qualify for educational benefits (free & reduced lunch).

As guides embark on our planning phase for distance learning options, we require important information on what resources your family needs during this school closure. Please fill out this survey ASAP to help us best plan to serve all of our families.
We're continuing to update this frequently asked question document - check there for answers to common questions before emailing office@greatriverschool.org.

p.strong: We will continue to update the community as details develop. The Calendar below is for your reference for the next 3 weeks.

div.class: image-block-outer-wrapper layout-caption-below design-layout-inline combination-animation-none individual-animation-none individual-text-animation-none

span.data-title: GRS Closed 3/17; REQUIRED FAMILY SURVEY INSIDE

article.class: entry h-entry hentry category-upper-adolescent category-lower-adolescent category-elementary category-bridge author-charlie-zieke post-type-text article-index-17

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge
Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge

div.p: Great River Families,

We learned this morning that Governor Tim Walz is closing Minnesota schools March 18th through March 27th. Great River School will be closed from March 18-27 in accordance with MDE and from March 30-April 3 for spring break. This means NO SCHOOL March 18th-April 3rd.

As of now (3/15/20) GRS plans to hold school again on April 6th, while we also acknowledge that the pandemic response is fluid and will change over time. We will continue to let families know if and when school is scheduled.
Basics of what we know:

li.p: a. Staff will deliver in-person education.
b. Administration will survey families to confirm access to phone, internet, and digital resources.

p.strong: Childcare for some: If you are a healthcare worker (nurse, PA, MD) or civil emergency worker (Law, Fire, EMT) or your family qualifies for educational benefits (free & reduced lunch) your child will be provided in-person childcare for GRS students 3/18-3/27

li.p: a. No care for any children 3/30-4/3 (Spring Break)
b. Contact office@greatriverschool.org if you’re a worker who qualifies for care.
Provide written confirmation of employment by 3/17/2020 at noon.

div.p: GRS will be in touch with families regularly 3/18-3/27 with updates on plans for 4/6 and beyond. We will provide specifics about access, communication, and planning. In the meantime, we’ve started a frequently-asked question document here. Keep in touch with your questions at office@greatriverschool.org.
Thank you all,

Sam O’Brien
Head of School

article.class: entry h-entry hentry category-upper-adolescent category-elementary category-lower-adolescent category-bridge author-charlie-zieke post-type-text article-index-18

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Elementary, Lower Adolescent, Bridge

h1.a: Coronavirus Mitigation Communication for Families at Great River

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Elementary, Lower Adolescent, Bridge

div.p: Hello Great River Community,

We are working with state Education and Health officials and our school authorizer to respond to the COVID19 pandemic. We anticipate continuing updates from MN State agencies - and we will keep all families updated as we hear more news. Important delays or cancelations are included below - including canceling the invitation to bring pies in or food for potlucks, and postponing gatherings and events.
Below is what we have to share now regarding:

li.p: Possible resources and next steps -“what are we doing and what will we do” (page 3)

div.p: MN does not have cases yet confirmed spread through community contact. Great River School does not have any cases of COVID-19. However, we are in close communication with the Minnesota Department of Health to proactively plan to both meet our public school duties and prevent the spread of infectious disease. To that end, we are following CDC guidelines of handwashing and other preventative measures and are in close communication with Minnesota Departments of Health & Education. We follow the CDC’s current guidelines, which have us in a state of “preparedness”.

We are considering further steps for prevention, and will stay in regular contact with families on actions. At least once per week each Thursday afternoon we will send an update to the whole community until the pandemic wanes. This weekly update begins today, 3/12/2020. If a case is suspected, public health officials will identify the student or staff member and will then provide direction on how the school should respond. The Minnesota Department of Health will determine if any travelers returning from affected areas should avoid work, school or other public areas. Schools do not screen students or staff for COVID-19.

If you are self-quarantining as a family preventative measure, please contact us directly right away at office@greatriverschool.org. We are working to provide guidance on at-home learning options for students by Tuesday 3/17/20.

I welcome the Great River community to engage in generosity by considering donation to a local food shelf. Many families are in need of sustenance in unexpected times - and will visit the food shelf again or for the first time in the midst of this pandemic. Please read on the following pages for important information and details.
May we all sustain our health and sanity together!
Sam O’Brien
Head of School

p.strong: For more information about the coronavirus:

li.p: Call the Minnesota Department of Health at 651-201-5414
View the CDC fact sheet on COVID-19
Information from the Minnesota Department of Health

div.class: image-block-outer-wrapper layout-caption-below design-layout-inline combination-animation-none individual-animation-none individual-text-animation-none

div.p: The Blue Heron Bash School Fundraiser needs your help!

Volunteers will be curbside at drop off on Energy Lane on Friday morning to collect bottles of wine to be used in the wine pull at the event. Our goal is to get 100 bottles. This service will be offered a couple more times before the event on March 21st.

If you are unable to drop off at this time you can always make your donation to Holly at the front desk. Thanks for your support & we hope to see you at the Bash! Click here for more information and to buy tickets!

article.class: entry h-entry hentry category-upper-adolescent category-lower-adolescent category-elementary category-bridge author-charlie-zieke post-type-text article-index-20

div.span: Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge
Upper Adolescent, Lower Adolescent, Elementary, Bridge

div.p: Ever wanted to give bartending a try? How about styling food in beautiful arrangements? Will you need a short break from adult conversation during the Bash? Spend an hour in the kitchen helping put out tasty bites. Perhaps you are longing for the holidays and would like to spend some time with light strings on Friday? There are lots of ways to volunteer. Check out the signup here.
If you don’t see something that suits you, send us an email at blueheronbash@greatriverschool.org and we’ll brainstorm more options! We couldn’t pull it off without your help.
